Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor suggested some optional reading and the informal deadline is weeks away.
Expectation2: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation2: An automated compliance system flags any minute of unscheduled downtime for possible disciplinary action.
Story:
I sat at my cramped desk, headset pressing into my ears, the hum of the call center a constant background drone. My mentor had emailed me that morning, suggesting a few articles to read—nothing urgent, just “whenever you have time.” I wanted to impress her, to show I was eager and committed, even if the deadline was weeks away. But as I opened the first article on my phone, the compliance system’s timer blinked at me from the corner of my screen. Every minute I wasn’t on a call was logged, and I’d already been warned about unscheduled breaks. If I got flagged again, it could mean a formal warning or worse.

I tried to focus on the article, but my eyes kept darting to the timer. I could hear my supervisor’s voice in my head, reminding us that every second counted. But I also imagined my mentor’s disappointment if I showed up unprepared at our next meeting. My stomach twisted as I weighed the risk of reading now against the fear of letting her down. The cursor blinked, the phone lines buzzed, and I sat frozen, torn between two worlds that seemed impossible to reconcile.
